wiki_catalogs.name: System Overview
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the Expense-Tracker---Warp application. Explain its purpose as a mobile-first, offline-capable expense tracking PWA with analytics and user settings. Describe the core goals: enabling users to track expenses, manage income, view financial insights via a dashboard, and maintain data integrity across online and offline states. Cover the target audience (individuals managing personal finances) and highlight key features including authentication, real-time dashboard analytics, category-based spending breakdowns, and automatic sync when reconnecting online. Discuss the architectural philosophy of being offline-first and full-stack using Convex as a backend-as-a-service. Include integration points between frontend (Next.js) and backend (Convex), emphasizing seamless developer experience and end-user reliability. Provide high-level diagrams illustrating system context and user workflows such as onboarding, expense entry, and syncing. Make this accessible to beginners while offering technical depth for developers evaluating the codebase.

wiki_catalogs.name: Convex Backend Directory
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the convex/ directory, which houses all backend logic and data modeling for the Expense-Tracker---Warp application. Explain the role of schema.ts in defining data models (User, Expense, Category, ForValue, UserSettings) and enforcing type safety across the full stack. Detail auth.ts as the authentication module handling user registration, login, and session management via Convex's authentication primitives. Describe expenses.ts as the core module for expense CRUD operations with proper access control and data validation. Cover userSettings.ts for managing user preferences like currency and calendar settings. Explain cardsAndIncome.ts for tracking income sources and card balances. Clarify the _generated/ directory's purpose in providing type-safe API bindings (api.d.ts, server.d.ts) for frontend consumption. Illustrate how Convex functions enable secure, real-time data synchronization and serverless mutations. Include examples of defining a new Convex query or mutation, and explain how frontend components invoke these via useMutation and useQuery hooks. Address security considerations such as function permissions and data validation best practices.

wiki_catalogs.name: Component Tree and Provider Hierarchy
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the root component tree and provider composition in the Expense-Tracker---Warp application. Explain how RootLayout in layout.tsx wraps the entire application with ConvexProvider, AuthContext, SettingsContext, and OfflineContext providers to enable global state access. Detail the order of provider nesting and its significance for dependency resolution (e.g., AuthContext requiring ConvexClient). Illustrate how ProtectedRoute leverages AuthContext to conditionally render authenticated routes. Include a diagram showing the provider hierarchy and data flow from top-level providers to leaf components. Document best practices for extending this structure with new providers, such as ensuring proper scoping and avoiding prop drilling. Provide code examples from layout.tsx and provider implementations to demonstrate initialization patterns and error boundaries.

wiki_catalogs.name: Purpose and Goals
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the core purpose and strategic goals of the Expense-Tracker---Warp application. Explain its mission to empower individuals with intuitive, reliable tools for personal financial management in both online and offline environments. Detail the primary objectives: enabling seamless expense and income tracking, delivering actionable insights through real-time analytics, supporting multiple currencies and calendar systems, and ensuring data persistence across network interruptions. Highlight the emphasis on mobile-first UX with PWA capabilities for installability and offline access. Discuss how the application balances simplicity for novice users with robust functionality for power users, leveraging Convex for real-time synchronization and data integrity. Include user personas such as budget-conscious individuals, freelancers tracking irregular income, and travelers managing multi-currency expenses. Provide examples from the codebase showing goal alignment, such as use of localforage for offline storage and Tailwind CSS for responsive design. Address non-goals (e.g., banking integration, tax calculation) to clarify scope boundaries.

wiki_catalogs.name: Authentication Data Flow
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the authentication data flow in the Expense-Tracker---Warp application. Explain the complete lifecycle from user login/register → credential submission → Convex auth mutation → JWT token generation and storage in localStorage → AuthContext state update → protected route access. Detail how AuthContext provides currentUser and loading states to components, and how it integrates with ProtectedRoute to redirect unauthenticated users. Document the role of Convex's authentication functions in validating credentials and managing sessions. Include code examples showing login form submission, token handling, and context consumption. Illustrate error handling for invalid credentials and expired sessions. Address security considerations: token storage safety, XSS protection, and session persistence. Provide debugging tips for common issues like silent authentication failures or context not updating.

wiki_catalogs.name: Authentication System
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Authentication System. Explain the implementation of user registration, login, session management, and token persistence using Convex backend functions and React Context. Document the flow from UI forms to backend authentication logic, including password hashing and token handling. Include code examples from auth.ts for mutation logic and AuthContext.tsx for state management. Describe integration with ProtectedRoute to restrict access to authenticated users only. Address common issues such as failed logins, session expiration, and offline authentication limitations. Provide guidance on extending the system with OAuth providers or multi-factor authentication.

wiki_catalogs.name: Data Models and Schema
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the Convex backend schema. Detail each entity defined in schema.ts: User (with fields _id, username, hashedPassword, tokenIdentifier), Expense (amount, title, category[], for[], date, createdAt, userId, cardId), Category (name, userId), ForValue (value, userId), and UserSettings (currency, calendar, userId). Explain field types, primary keys, and relationships between collections. Document validation rules such as required fields, string length constraints, and numeric ranges. Illustrate entity-relationship diagrams showing how Expenses reference Users and Categories, and how Settings are scoped per User. Describe how Convex schema definitions translate into auto-generated TypeScript types in dataModel.d.ts. Include examples of valid and invalid documents. Discuss indexing strategies for query performance, especially on userId and date fields. Address data lifecycle considerations including deletion cascading and retention policies.

wiki_catalogs.name: Authentication API
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create RESTful API documentation for the authentication module in the Convex backend. Document each function: login (accepts username and password, returns session token), register (creates new user with hashed password, validates uniqueness), and getCurrentUser (returns authenticated user data). Specify function signatures, parameter types (e.g., string for username/password), and return structures (User object or null). Detail authentication flow including token handling via Convex auth and session persistence. Include examples of calling these from the frontend using useMutation('auth/login') and useQuery('auth/getCurrentUser'). Explain error responses such as invalid credentials (401), duplicate username (409), and validation failures. Document how types in _generated/api.d.ts provide compile-time safety for these calls. Provide simulated curl examples using Convex HTTP API endpoints. Highlight security practices like password hashing and token expiration. Address common issues like session expiration and input validation errors.

wiki_catalogs.name: Data Modeling with schema.ts
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the schema.ts file, which defines the core data structures of the Expense-Tracker---Warp application. Detail each collection: User (authentication and session data), Expense (financial transactions with category and for fields), Category (user-specific spending categories), ForValue (custom 'for' values like people or events), and UserSettings (currency, calendar preferences). Explain how Convex schema declarations enforce type safety and data integrity through TypeScript interfaces and validation rules. Illustrate entity relationships, such as userId foreign keys linking expenses and settings to users. Document field types, required vs optional properties, and indexing strategies for query performance. Include examples of extending the schema with new fields or collections, and explain how changes propagate to the _generated/ directory for full-stack type safety. Address best practices for schema evolution and migration strategies.

wiki_catalogs.name: App Router - Page Routes and Layouts
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Next.js App Router structure located in src/app/. Explain how each directory corresponds to a route (e.g., /dashboard, /expenses, /settings) and how page.tsx files define the UI for those routes. Detail layout.tsx for shared UI elements and root layout wrapping providers. Describe dynamic routing in /expenses/edit/[id]/page.tsx and /income/edit/[id]/page.tsx with parameter handling. Illustrate how ProtectedRoute is used to guard access to authenticated pages like /dashboard and /settings. Provide examples of adding new pages, nesting layouts, and integrating server components with client-side hooks. Address common issues such as route loading states, error handling, and data fetching patterns using Convex queries. Include best practices for route organization and performance optimization.

wiki_catalogs.name: Auth Context Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the AuthContext state management system. Explain how it uses React Context to manage user authentication state across the application, including login, registration, and session persistence via localStorage. Document the integration with Convex auth functions for secure token handling and user validation. Illustrate how ProtectedRoute consumes AuthContext to enforce access control on private routes. Include examples of context provider setup in layout.tsx and consumer patterns in UI components. Address edge cases such as token expiration, offline login state, and race conditions during hydration. Provide best practices for error handling, loading states, and avoiding re-render bottlenecks using memoization. Show how AuthContext interacts with OfflineContext for seamless offline authentication experiences.

wiki_catalogs.name: Reusable UI Components Library
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the core reusable UI components that form the foundation of the application's interface. Explain how SmartSelectInput provides an accessible, searchable dropdown with dynamic options and validation states, including its integration with form handling logic. Detail CustomDatePicker's implementation using native date inputs with fallbacks for mobile PWA compatibility and theming via Tailwind. Describe HeaderRow's role in displaying contextual time filters across pages and its composition with DateFilterHeader for consistent UX. Cover BottomNav's navigation structure with active state indicators and PWA installability considerations. Document NetworkStatusIndicator and OfflineBanner's real-time feedback mechanisms using OfflineContext, including visual states and animation patterns. Provide code examples showing component composition, props interfaces, and event handling. Address accessibility features, responsive behavior, and performance implications of re-renders. Include guidance on extending these components with new variants while maintaining design consistency.

wiki_catalogs.name: Technology Stack
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the technology stack of the Expense-Tracker---Warp application. Detail each technology used and its role: Next.js App Router for server-side rendering and routing, React 18 for component-based UI, TypeScript for type safety across frontend and backend, Tailwind CSS for utility-first styling, Convex for full-stack backend services including database, functions, and real-time sync, localforage for IndexedDB-backed offline storage, Sonner for toast notifications, and Workbox via sw.js for service worker management in PWA. Explain version compatibility, integration patterns (e.g., ConvexProvider wrapping the app), and rationale behind choosing these tools (developer velocity, offline support, type safety). Include configuration snippets from next.config.mjs and tailwind.config.ts showing module resolutions and theme definitions. Address how these technologies collectively enable PWA installability, offline functionality, and responsive design. Provide performance implications and best practices for using each technology within this project context.

wiki_catalogs.name: Src Directory - Frontend Source Code
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the src/ directory, which contains all frontend source code for the Next.js application. Break down app/ as the App Router structure defining routes like /dashboard, /expenses, /settings, and protected routes using layout.tsx and page.tsx files. Explain components/ as the repository for reusable UI elements such as ExpenseCard.tsx, IncomeCard.tsx, CustomDatePicker.tsx, and SmartSelectInput.tsx. Detail contexts/ for global state management via AuthContext.tsx (authentication state), OfflineContext.tsx (offline detection and sync), and SettingsContext.tsx (user preferences). Describe providers/ with ConvexProvider.tsx initializing the Convex client for real-time data access. Cover hooks/ for shared logic like useDebounce.ts and useTimeFramedData.ts. Explain lib/ containing formatters.ts for currency and date formatting utilities. Illustrate how these layers integrate: RootLayout wraps all providers, ProtectedRoute guards authenticated access, and pages consume data via Convex hooks. Provide guidance on adding new pages, creating components, and extending context providers while maintaining type safety and separation of concerns.

wiki_catalogs.name: State Management Patterns
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content on the state management architecture of the frontend, focusing on React Context and custom hooks. Explain how AuthContext manages user authentication state using Convex auth functions and localStorage persistence. Describe OfflineContext's use of localforage to sync IndexedDB with Convex when online, including queue management for pending operations. Detail SettingsContext's handling of user preferences like currency and calendar. Show how custom hooks like useExpenseData abstract data fetching logic and integrate with Convex queries. Contrast Context for global state vs. custom hooks for feature-specific logic. Provide examples of context consumers accessing state safely with loading and error states. Address performance considerations like minimizing re-renders with memoization and proper context splitting.

wiki_catalogs.name: Target Audience
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for this section identifying and characterizing the target audience of Expense-Tracker---Warp. Break down user segments including personal finance beginners seeking simple expense logging, tech-savvy users valuing offline capabilities, mobile-first users preferring PWA installation, and data-driven individuals interested in spending analytics. Explain how the UI/UX caters to each group—for example, onboarding flow for newcomers, dashboard visualizations for analysts, and manual sync controls for advanced users. Reference specific components like ProtectedRoute.tsx that ensure secure access for authenticated users, and SettingsContext.tsx that enables personalization. Discuss accessibility considerations in components like SmartSelectInput and responsive layouts using Tailwind CSS. Include guidance on how documentation should adapt tone and depth for different audience segments, with beginner-friendly tutorials versus API references for developers extending the app.

wiki_catalogs.name: Offline Data Flow and Synchronization
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the offline data flow and synchronization mechanism. Explain how OfflineContext detects network status using navigator.onLine and maintains an IndexedDB queue via localforage for pending operations. Detail the interception of Convex mutations when offline, serialization of operation metadata (function name, arguments, timestamp), and storage in the local queue. Describe the automatic sync process: reconnection detection, sequential execution of queued operations, conflict resolution on server response, and local cache invalidation. Illustrate the role of the service worker (sw.js) in enabling PWA offline capabilities and background sync. Include examples of adding an expense while offline and observing the sync process upon reconnection. Address edge cases: partial sync failures, duplicate entries, and user logout during offline mode. Provide logging strategies and tools to monitor offline queue state and sync progress.

wiki_catalogs.name: Expense Management

Document the interaction between frontend components and Convex mutations in expenses.ts. Use examples from ExpenseCard.tsx and edit/[id]/page.tsx to illustrate data binding and submission patterns. Explain validation rules, error handling, and success feedback using Sonner notifications. Address offline behavior when adding or editing expenses and how pending operations are synced. Provide customization options for adding tags, recurrence, or attachments in future extensions.

Explain how session tokens are generated and validated. Describe the integration between frontend AuthContext and these backend functions. Include request/response signatures from api.d.ts, showing parameter types and return structures. Provide examples of successful and failed authentication flows. Address security considerations including rate limiting, brute force protection, and secure token handling. Document error types such as invalid credentials or duplicate usernames.

wiki_overview.content:
# Comprehensive Analysis of PWA Expense Tracker App ## 1. Project Introduction ### Purpose Statement The PWA Expense Tracker App is a mobile-first, installable Progressive Web Application designed to help users track their daily expenses with full offline support. The application provides a seamless experience across devices while maintaining data integrity even when connectivity is lost. ### Core Goals and Objectives - Provide a robust expense tracking solution with comprehensive categorization capabilities - Ensure full functionality in offline mode with automatic synchronization when connectivity is restored - Deliver a native-like experience through PWA capabilities on both mobile and desktop platforms - Implement secure authentication and data persistence for personal financial information ### Target Audience The application targets individuals who need to track their personal or business expenses on-the-go, particularly those who frequently experience connectivity issues or prefer a mobile-first interface. The installable PWA nature makes it ideal for users who want app-like functionality without downloading from app stores. ## 2. Technical Architecture ### Component Breakdown The application follows a clean architectural separation between frontend and backend components, leveraging Next.js for the frontend and Convex for the backend services. ```mermaid graph TD A[Client] --> B[API Layer] B --> C[Business Logic] C --> D[Data Access] D --> E[(Convex Database)] F[Service Worker] --> G[IndexedDB] H[AuthContext] --> I[LocalStorage] J[OfflineContext] --> G K[ConvexProvider] --> L[Convex Backend] ``` ### Design Patterns The application implements several key design patterns: - **Context API Pattern**: Authentication, offline, and settings states are managed through React Context, providing global state management without prop drilling - **Provider Pattern**: Multiple providers wrap the application in the root layout, establishing a clear dependency hierarchy - **Custom Hooks**: Business logic is abstracted into reusable custom hooks like `useExpenseData` and `useTimeFramedData` - **Component Composition**: Complex UI elements are built through composition of smaller, focused components ### System Relationships The system demonstrates a well-organized relationship between frontend and backend components: ```mermaid graph LR A[Frontend] --> B[Convex Backend] A --> C[IndexedDB] A --> D[LocalStorage] B --> E[Convex Database] F[Service Worker] --> A F --> C G[PWA Manifest] --> A ``` ### Data Flow The data flow follows a predictable pattern from user interaction to persistence: ```mermaid flowchart TD A[User Input] --> B[React State] B --> C[Form Validation] C --> D{Online?} D -->|Yes| E[Convex API] D -->|No| F[IndexedDB Queue] E --> G[Convex Database] F --> H[Service Worker Sync] H --> E E --> I[React Query Cache] I --> J[UI Components] ``` ## 3. Implementation Details ### Main Entry Points The application's entry point is structured around Next.js App Router conventions: ```typescript "use client"; import { useEffect } from "react"; import { useRouter } from "next/navigation"; import { useAuth } from "@/contexts/AuthContext"; export default function Home() { const { user, loading } = useAuth(); const router = useRouter(); useEffect(() => { if (!loading) { if (user) { router.replace("/expenses"); } else { router.replace("/login"); } } }, [user, loading, router]); if (loading) { return (
Loading...
); } return null; } ``` Sources: - [page.tsx](src/app/page.tsx#L1-L31) ### Core Modules #### Authentication System The authentication system is implemented with a combination of frontend and backend components: ```typescript // Frontend context manages authentication state const AuthContext = createContext(undefined); export function AuthProvider({ children }: { children: ReactNode }) { const [token, setToken] = useState(null); const [loading, setLoading] = useState(true); const loginMutation = useMutation(api.auth.login); const registerMutation = useMutation(api.auth.register); const logoutMutation = useMutation(api.auth.logout); const user = useQuery(api.auth.getCurrentUser, token ? { token } : "skip"); useEffect(() => { const savedToken = localStorage.getItem("auth-token"); if (savedToken) { setToken(savedToken); } setLoading(false); }, []); const login = async (username: string, password: string) => { try { const result = await loginMutation({ username, password }); setToken(result.token); localStorage.setItem("auth-token", result.token); } catch (error) { throw error; } }; ``` Sources: - [AuthContext.tsx](src/contexts/AuthContext.tsx#L1-L97) #### Offline Functionality Offline support is implemented through a sophisticated context that manages pending operations: ```typescript const OfflineContext = createContext(undefined); export function OfflineProvider({ children }: { children: ReactNode }) { const [isOnline, setIsOnline] = useState(true); const [pendingExpenses, setPendingExpenses] = useState([]); const { token } = useAuth(); const createExpenseMutation = useMutation(api.expenses.createExpense); useEffect(() => { localforage.config({ name: 'ExpenseTracker', storeName: 'pending_expenses', description: 'Queue for offline expense submissions', }); const loadPendingExpenses = async () => { try { const saved = await localforage.getItem('pending-expenses'); if (saved) { setPendingExpenses(saved); } } catch (error) { console.error("Failed to load pending expenses from IndexedDB:", error); } }; loadPendingExpenses(); const handleOnline = () => setIsOnline(true); const handleOffline = () => setIsOnline(false); window.addEventListener("online", handleOnline); window.addEventListener("offline", handleOffline); setIsOnline(navigator.onLine); return () => { window.removeEventListener("online", handleOnline); window.removeEventListener("offline", handleOffline); }; }, []); ``` Sources: - [OfflineContext.tsx](src/contexts/OfflineContext.tsx#L1-L172) ### Configuration Approach #### Next.js PWA Configuration The application is configured as a PWA using next-pwa with specific caching strategies: ```javascript import withPWA from 'next-pwa'; const isProduction = process.env.NODE_ENV === 'production'; const nextConfig = { // Next.js config }; const pwaConfig = { dest: 'public', register: true, skipWaiting: true, disable: !isProduction, runtimeCaching: [ { urlPattern: /\/dashboard/, handler: 'StaleWhileRevalidate', options: { cacheName: 'dashboard-cache', expiration: { maxEntries: 1, maxAgeSeconds: 24 * 60 * 60, // 1 day }, }, }, { urlPattern: /\/expenses/, handler: 'NetworkFirst', options: { cacheName: 'expenses-cache', expiration: { maxEntries: 1, maxAgeSeconds: 24 * 60 * 60, // 1 day }, }, }, { urlPattern: ({ url }) => url.protocol.startsWith('https') && url.hostname.endsWith('.convex.cloud'), handler: 'NetworkFirst', options: { cacheName: 'convex-api-cache', networkTimeoutSeconds: 10, expiration: { maxEntries: 50, }, backgroundSync: { name: 'convex-mutations-queue', options: { maxRetentionTime: 24 * 60, // Retry for up to 24 hours }, }, cacheableResponse: { statuses: [0, 200], }, }, }, ], }; export default withPWA(pwaConfig)(nextConfig); ``` Sources: - [next.config.mjs](next.config.mjs#L1-L75) #### Service Worker Implementation The service worker provides basic caching for offline functionality: ```javascript const CACHE_NAME = 'expense-tracker-v1'; const urlsToCache = [ '/', '/login', '/register', '/expenses', '/dashboard', '/settings', '/manifest.json', '/icon-192.png', '/icon-512.png' ]; // Install event - cache resources self.addEventListener('install', (event) => { event.waitUntil( caches.open(CACHE_NAME) .then((cache) => { return cache.addAll(urlsToCache); }) ); }); // Fetch event - serve from cache when offline self.addEventListener('fetch', (event) => { event.respondWith( caches.match(event.request) .then((response) => { // Return cached version or fetch from network return response || fetch(event.request); } ) ); }); ``` Sources: - [sw.js](public/sw.js#L1-L50) ### External Dependencies #### Convex Integration The application integrates with Convex for backend services: ```typescript "use client"; import { ConvexProvider as ConvexReactProvider } from "convex/react"; import { ConvexReactClient } from "convex/react"; import { ReactNode } from "react"; const convex = new ConvexReactClient(process.env.NEXT_PUBLIC_CONVEX_URL!); export function ConvexProvider({ children }: { children: ReactNode }) { return ( {children} ); } ``` Sources: - [ConvexProvider.tsx](src/providers/ConvexProvider.tsx#L1-L16) #### Root Layout with Context Providers The application's context providers are composed in the root layout: ```typescript export default function RootLayout({ children, }: Readonly<{ children: React.ReactNode; }>) { return ( {children}
); } ``` Sources: - [layout.tsx](src/app/layout.tsx#L1-L59) ### Component Relationships The component hierarchy demonstrates a well-organized structure: ```mermaid graph TD A[RootLayout] --> B[ConvexProvider] A --> C[AuthProvider] A --> D[SettingsProvider] A --> E[OfflineProvider] B --> F[App Content] C --> F D --> F E --> F F --> G[ProtectedRoute] G --> H[ExpensePage] G --> I[DashboardPage] H --> J[SmartSelectInput] H --> K[CustomDatePicker] I --> L[CategoryBreakdownChart] I --> M[DailySpendingChart] E --> N[OfflineBanner] A --> O[NetworkStatusIndicator] ``` ## 4. Key Features ### Authentication Implementation The authentication system is implemented with both frontend and backend components: ```typescript // Backend authentication functions export const register = mutation({ args: { username: v.string(), password: v.string(), }, handler: async (ctx, args) => { // Check if user already exists const existingUser = await ctx.db .query("users") .withIndex("by_username", (q) => q.eq("username", args.username)) .first(); if (existingUser) { throw new ConvexError("Username already exists"); } // Create new user const hashedPassword = hashPassword(args.password); const tokenIdentifier = generateToken(); const userId = await ctx.db.insert("users", { username: args.username, hashedPassword, tokenIdentifier, }); return { userId, token: tokenIdentifier }; }, }); ``` Sources: - [auth.ts](convex/auth.ts#L1-L132) ### Expense Management The expense management system supports comprehensive tracking with category and attribution fields: ```typescript export const createExpense = mutation({ args: { token: v.string(), amount: v.number(), title: v.string(), category: v.array(v.string()), for: v.array(v.string()), date: v.number(), cardId: v.optional(v.id("cards")), }, handler: async (ctx, args) => { const user = await getUserByToken(ctx, args.token); const expense = await ctx.db.insert("expenses", { amount: args.amount, title: args.title, category: args.category, for: args.for, date: args.date, createdAt: Date.now(), userId: user._id, cardId: args.cardId, }); // Add categories to user's categories if they don't exist for (const categoryName of args.category) { const existingCategory = await ctx.db .query("categories") .withIndex("by_user_name", (q) => q.eq("userId", user._id).eq("name", categoryName)) .first(); if (!existingCategory) { await ctx.db.insert("categories", { name: categoryName, userId: user._id, }); } } ``` Sources: - [expenses.ts](convex/expenses.ts#L1-L325) ### Dashboard & Analytics The dashboard provides comprehensive analytics with interactive charts: ```typescript export function useExpenseData(token: string | null) { const [currentDate, setCurrentDate] = useState(new Date()); // Fetch expenses for the current month const result = useQuery( api.expenses.getExpensesByDateRange, token ? { token, startDate: startOfMonth(currentDate).getTime(), endDate: endOfMonth(currentDate).getTime(), key, } : "skip" ); const expenses = result as unknown as Expense[] | undefined; const isLoading = result === undefined; // Process the expense data to get monthly summaries const monthlyData = useMemo(() => { if (!expenses) return null; const totalAmount = expenses.reduce((sum, expense) => sum + expense.amount, 0); const totalCount = expenses.length; // Calculate category totals const categoryTotals = expenses.reduce>((acc, expense) => { const categories = Array.isArray(expense.category) ? expense.category : [expense.category]; categories.forEach((cat) => { acc[cat] = (acc[cat] || 0) + expense.amount; }); return acc; }, {}); // Calculate daily totals const dailyTotals = expenses.reduce>((acc, expense) => { const date = new Date(expense.date); const dayKey = date.toLocaleDateString('en-US', { month: 'short', day: 'numeric' }); acc[dayKey] = (acc[dayKey] || 0) + expense.amount; return acc; }, {}); return { totalAmount, totalCount, categoryTotals, dailyTotals, }; }, [expenses]); ``` Sources: - [useExpenseData.ts](src/features/dashboard/hooks/useExpenseData.ts#L1-L87) ### Offline Support The offline functionality is implemented through multiple layers: ```typescript const syncPendingExpenses = async () => { if (!token || !isOnline) return; const expensesToSync = pendingExpenses.filter(e => e.status === 'pending' || e.status === 'failed'); if (expensesToSync.length === 0) return; for (const expense of expensesToSync) { await updateExpenseStatus(expense.id, 'syncing'); try { await createExpenseMutation({ token, amount: expense.amount, title: expense.title, category: expense.category, for: expense.for, date: expense.date, }); // On success, remove it from the pending list const remainingExpenses = pendingExpenses.filter(e => e.id !== expense.id); setPendingExpenses(remainingExpenses); await localforage.setItem('pending-expenses', remainingExpenses); } catch (error) { console.error(`Failed to sync expense ${expense.id}:`, error); await updateExpenseStatus(expense.id, 'failed'); } } }; ``` Sources: - [OfflineContext.tsx](src/contexts/OfflineContext.tsx#L1-L172) ### Mobile & PWA Features The application is designed with mobile-first principles and PWA capabilities: ```typescript export const OfflineBanner: React.FC = () => { const { isOnline, pendingExpenses } = useOffline(); if (isOnline) return null; return (
You are offline. {pendingExpenses.length} pending expense {pendingExpenses.length === 1 ? "" : "s"} will sync when you're back online.
); }; ``` Sources: - [OfflineBanner.tsx](src/components/OfflineBanner.tsx#L1-L27) ### Feature Architecture The application's feature architecture follows a clear state management pattern: ```mermaid stateDiagram-v2 [*] --> Initial Initial --> Authenticated: Login/Register Initial --> Unauthenticated: No Token Authenticated --> Dashboard: Navigate Authenticated --> Expenses: Navigate Authenticated --> Settings: Navigate Expenses --> AddExpense: Form Submit AddExpense --> Online: Connected AddExpense --> Offline: Disconnected Online --> Synced: Immediate Sync Offline --> Queued: Store Locally Queued --> Synced: Connection Restored Dashboard --> ViewAnalytics: Display Charts Settings --> ManualSync: User Request ManualSync --> SyncPending: Process Queue ```

wiki_readme.content:
# 💰 PWA Expense Tracker App

A mobile-first, installable Progressive Web App (PWA) for tracking daily expenses with offline support.

## 🎯 Features

### ✅ Authentication
- [x] Custom username/password authentication
- [x] User registration and login
- [x] Persistent auth sessions
- [x] Secure logout functionality

### ✅ Expense Management
- [x] Add expenses with amount, title, categories, and date
- [x] Tag-based category system with auto-suggestions
- [x] Multiple categories per expense
- [x] Optional "for" field for expense attribution
- [x] Optimistic updates for better UX

### ✅ Dashboard & Analytics
- [x] Monthly expense summaries
- [x] Month navigation (previous/next)
- [x] Interactive pie chart for category breakdown
- [x] Bar chart for daily spending patterns
- [x] Responsive charts for mobile devices

### ✅ Offline Support
- [x] IndexedDB for local data caching
- [x] Offline expense creation queue
- [x] Automatic sync when connection restored
- [x] Offline status banner
- [x] Manual sync option

### ✅ Mobile & PWA
- [x] Mobile-first responsive design
- [x] Touch-friendly UI (44px minimum touch targets)
- [x] Installable as native app
- [x] Service worker for offline functionality
- [x] Bottom navigation for mobile
- [x] Framer Motion animations

## 🧱 Tech Stack

- **Frontend**: Next.js 14 (App Router), TypeScript, Tailwind CSS
- **Backend**: Convex (database + real-time functions)
- **Auth**: Custom username/password with Convex
- **Charts**: Chart.js with react-chartjs-2
- **Animations**: Framer Motion
- **Offline**: IndexedDB + Service Worker
- **UI**: Lucide React icons, Sonner toasts
- **Forms**: React Hook Form with Zod validation

## 🚀 Getting Started

### Prerequisites
- Node.js 18+ 
- npm or yarn

### Installation

1. **Clone the repository**
   ```bash
   git clone <repository-url>
   cd warp-ex-tracker
   ```

2. **Install dependencies**
   ```bash
   npm install
   ```

3. **Set up Convex**
   ```bash
   npx convex dev
   ```
   This will:
   - Create a new Convex project
   - Generate `.env.local` with your Convex URL
   - Set up the database schema
   - Deploy backend functions

4. **Start the development server**
   ```bash
   npm run dev
   ```

5. **Open in your browser**
   Navigate to `http://localhost:3000`

### Building for Production

```bash
npm run build
npm start
```

## 📱 PWA Installation

### On Mobile (iOS/Android)
1. Open the app in Safari (iOS) or Chrome (Android)
2. Tap the share button
3. Select "Add to Home Screen"
4. The app will appear as a native app icon

### On Desktop
1. Open the app in Chrome/Edge
2. Look for the install icon in the address bar
3. Click "Install" to add it as a desktop app

## 🌐 Usage

### First Time Setup
1. **Register**: Create an account with username and password
2. **Login**: Sign in to access your expense tracker

### Adding Expenses
1. Navigate to the "Expenses" tab
2. Fill in the expense form:
   - **Amount**: Enter the expense amount
   - **Title**: Brief description (e.g., "Lunch", "Gas")
   - **Categories**: Add tags by typing and pressing Enter
   - **For**: Optional field for attribution
   - **Date**: Select the expense date
3. Tap "Add Expense"

### Viewing Analytics
1. Go to the "Dashboard" tab
2. View monthly summaries with:
   - Total amount spent
   - Number of expenses
   - Category breakdown (pie chart)
   - Daily spending (bar chart)
3. Use arrow buttons to navigate between months

### Offline Usage
- The app works offline automatically
- Add expenses while offline - they'll be queued
- Orange banner shows offline status
- Expenses sync automatically when back online
- Manual sync available in Settings

### Settings
- View your profile information
- Check connection status
- Manual sync for offline expenses
- Logout option

## 🔧 Development

### Project Structure
```
src/
├── app/                 # Next.js App Router pages
│   ├── expenses/        # Main expense form page
│   ├── dashboard/       # Analytics dashboard
│   ├── settings/        # User settings
│   ├── login/          # Authentication
│   └── register/       # User registration
├── components/         # Reusable components
├── contexts/          # React contexts (Auth, Offline)
├── providers/         # Provider wrappers
convex/               # Backend functions and schema
├── schema.ts         # Database schema
├── auth.ts          # Authentication functions
└── expenses.ts      # Expense management functions
public/              # Static assets and PWA files
├── manifest.json    # PWA manifest
├── sw.js           # Service worker
└── *.png           # App icons
```

### Key Components
- `ProtectedRoute`: Authentication wrapper
- `OfflineBanner`: Shows offline status
- `BottomNav`: Mobile navigation
- `AuthContext`: Manages user authentication
- `OfflineContext`: Handles offline functionality

### Database Schema
```typescript
// Users
{
  username: string,
  hashedPassword: string,
  tokenIdentifier: string
}

// Expenses
{
  amount: number,
  title: string,
  category: string[],
  for?: string,
  date: number,
  createdAt: number,
  userId: Id<"users">
}

// Categories
{
  name: string,
  userId: Id<"users">
}
```

## 🚀 Deployment

### Vercel (Recommended)
1. Push code to GitHub
2. Connect repository to Vercel
3. Add environment variables:
   - `NEXT_PUBLIC_CONVEX_URL` (from `.env.local`)
4. Deploy automatically

### Manual Deployment
1. Build the app: `npm run build`
2. Deploy the `out` folder to any static hosting
3. Ensure environment variables are set

## 📈 Success Criteria

| Feature | Status | Notes |
|---------|--------|-------|
| Auth | ✅ | Register, login, logout all work |
| Expense Input | ✅ | All fields function, tags behave correctly |
| Dashboard | ✅ | Charts reflect monthly data correctly |
| Offline Usage | ✅ | App usable and consistent without internet |
| PWA | ✅ | Installable on Android/iOS via browser |
| Deployment | ✅ | Accessible via Vercel URL |

## 🐛 Known Issues & Limitations

- Service worker caching is basic (can be enhanced)
- No expense editing/deleting (future feature)
- Simple password hashing (use bcrypt in production)
- Limited to username/password auth (could add OAuth)

## 🔮 Future Enhancements

- Profile editing capabilities
- Expense editing and deletion
- Recurring expense tracking
- Search and filtering
- Data export functionality
- Multiple currency support
- Budget tracking and alerts
- Enhanced offline sync with conflict resolution

## 🤝 Contributing

1. Fork the repository
2. Create a feature branch
3. Make your changes
4. Test thoroughly
5. Submit a pull request

## 📄 License

MIT License - see LICENSE file for details

---

Built with ❤️ using Next.js, Convex, and modern web technologies.
